content: anything goes jumper uk terminology 2 strands dk worked double knit together to make c hunky marble chunky by jan 450g xl 1350m 600g size small 936m thank you to jan for her help in testing this pattern i absolutely love your version in james brett marble chunky this is an easy and versatile top down jumper that requires no seaming and has very few ends to sew in depending on how many colours you are using it is made to fit as you go it can be made in any weight yarn in a single colour in stripes or even using all the odds and ends of your left over yarn of the same yarn weight you can also use any stitch or hook depending on the e cid 431 ect you are after i have written the pattern using uk trebles but feel free to get creative this is a free patten written by unwind with us and must not be sold please feel free to sell your makes but credit us on your makes and any social media posts stitches uk terminology treble_crochet- treble_crochet slip_stitch slip_stitch chain chain sdc stacked double_crochet - https //youtu be/inociijwmfu invj invisible join - https //youtu be/7uw5i5smpgy fptr front post treble bptr back post treble neck we will start by making the neck ribbing do this by making chains in multiples of 6 and joining them with a slip_stitch make sure they are not twisted and that they fit over your head for example on my original jumper i had 72 stitches for the chunky weight and on version 2 which was dk i have done 90 if you want a relaxed neck you can make more but it will still need to be a multiple of 6 when you are happy with your chain count slip_stitch to the first chain to join and then chain 3 counts as a treble and treble into each stitch slip_stitch to the top of your chain 3 to join how many stitches did you make in your first row ___________ chain 3 counts as a bptr fptr bptr around and slip_stitch to third chain of the starting chain repeat this for another 3 rounds or as many as desired you will now need to do a little maths to work out where the increases need to be mark your corners making the first corner where your slip_stitch is from the neck total chains /6 = short sides total chains - short sides and 4 corners = long sides this is a free patten written by unwind with us and must not be sold please feel free to sell your makes but credit us on your makes and any social media posts for example my first version was a foundation chain of 72 72 / 6 = 12 stitches for the short sides 72 24 short sides 4 corners = 44 / 2 = 22 stitches for the long sides start r1 1 corner stich 1
